p: Evidence from previous investigations indicates that plant invasion can result in a significant change in the structure and function of the native ecosystem [ 50â€“ 52]. Invasion of B. alba is associated with changes in the soil environment of coastal zones, including pH and EC, predominantly due to selective absorption of N forms associated to a strong preference for ammonium (NH 4+) over nitrate (NO 3-) and alkaline substances in litter and root exudates of invasion plants [ 53, 54]. Obvious changes in pH and EC may interactively influence phylogenetic diversity associating with bacterial community functions [ 55].
